content.text: the name of a suitable measuring instrument,
how random errors may be reduced when using the instrument in (i)
For the measurement of the diameter of the wire, state
Show that the value of \(\sigma\) is \(1.99 \times 10^{8} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(\sigma\)
Use the information in **(b)**(i) and your answer in **(b)**(ii) to determine the value of \(\alpha\), with its absolute uncertainty, to an appropriate number of significant figures
The stress \(\sigma\) in the wire is calculated by using the expression
One end of a wire is connected to a fixed point. A load is attached to the other end so that the wire hangs vertically
The diameter \(d\) of the wire and the load \(F\) are measured as
Define the moment of a force
State an expression, in terms of \(r\), for the torque of the couple due to the forces at A and B acting on the disc
Friction between the disc and the pin is negligible
Determine the angle \(\theta\)
State the magnitude of the force of the pin on the disc
A thin disc of radius \(r\) is supported at its centre O by a pin. The disc is supported so that it is vertical. Three forces act in the plane of the disc, as shown in Fig. 2.1

Two horizontal and opposite forces, each of magnitude 1.2N, act at points A and B on the edge of the disc. A force of 6.0N, at an angle \(\theta\) below the horizontal, acts on the midpoint C of a radial line of the disc, as shown in Fig. 2.1. The disc has negligible weight and is in equilibrium
Calculate the difference in the pressure exerted by the water on the bottom face and on the top face of the cube
difference in pressure =   .........  \(Pa\)
Use your answer in (a) to show that the upthrust on the cube is 1.3N
Calculate the force exerted on the spring by the cube when it is in equilibrium in the water
The spring obeys Hooke's law and has a spring constant of \(30 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\)
Determine the initial height above the water surface of the base of the cube before it was released
height above surface =   .........  cm
Determine the initial acceleration of the cube
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
Describe and explain the variation, if any, of the acceleration of the cube as it sinks in the water
The cube in the water is released from the spring
A spring is attached at one end to a fixed point and hangs vertically with a cube attached to the other end. The cube is initially held so that the spring has zero extension, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Fig. 3.2

The cube has weight 4.0N and sides of length 5.1cm. The cube is released and sinks into water as the spring extends. The cube reaches equilibrium with its base at a depth of 7.0cm below the water surface, as shown in Fig. 3.2
The density of the water is \(1000 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
State the conditions required for the formation of a stationary wave
State the number of antinodes in the stationary wave
Determine the minimum time taken for the particle P to travel from its lowest point to its highest point
time taken =   .........  \(s\)
State the phase difference, with its unit, between the vibrations of particle P and of particle Q
phase difference =   .........
Determine the speed of a progressive wave along the string

A horizontal string is stretched between two fixed points X and Y. The string is made to vibrate vertically so that a stationary wave is formed. At one instant, each particle of the string is at its maximum displacement, as shown in Fig. 4.1
P and Q are two particles of the string. The string vibrates with a frequency of \(40\mathrm{Hz}\). Distance XY is \(2.0\mathrm{m}\)
Define the coulomb
Show that the electric force acting on the particle is \(4.0 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\)
On Fig. 5.1, draw labelled arrows to show the directions of the two forces acting on the smoke particle
The resultant force acting on the particle is \(F\)
Determine
1. the magnitude of \(F\),
magnitude =   .........  N
2. the angle of \(F\) to the horizontal

Two vertical metal plates in a vacuum have a separation of \(4.0 \text{cm}\). A potential difference of \(2.0 \times 10^{2} \text{V}\) is applied between the plates. Fig. 5.1 shows a side view of this arrangement
A smoke particle is in the uniform electric field between the plates. The particle has weight \(3.9 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\) and charge \(-8.0 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\)

The electric field in **(b)** is switched on at time \(t = 0\) when the particle is at a horizontal displacement \(s = 2.0 \text{cm}\) from the left-hand plate. At time \(t = 0\) the horizontal velocity of the particle is zero. The particle is then moved by the electric field until it hits a plate at time \(t = T\)
On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the horizontal displacement \(s\) of the particle from the left-hand plate
State what is meant by an electric current
State, in terms of \(A\), \(e\), \(L\) and \(n\), an expression for the total charge of the free electrons in the wire
Use your answer in (i) to show that the current \(I\) is given by the equation
A metal wire has length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 6.1
\(I\) is the current in the wire,
\(n\) is the number of free electrons per unit volume in the wire,
\(v\) is the average drift speed of a free electron and
\(e\) is the charge on an electron
Determine the ratio
average drift speed of free electrons at cross-section Y
average drift speed of free electrons at cross-section X
The main part of the wire with cross-section X has a resistance per unit length of \(1.7 \times 10^{-2} \Omega \text{m}^{-1}\)
For the damaged length of the wire, calculate
1. the resistance per unit length,
resistance per unit length =   .........  \(\Omega \mathrm{m}^{-1}\)
2. the power dissipated
The diameter of the damaged length of the wire is further decreased. Assume that the current in the wire remains constant
State and explain qualitatively the change, if any, to the power dissipated in the damaged length of the wire
A metal wire in a circuit is damaged. The resistivity of the metal is unchanged but the cross- sectional area of the wire is reduced over a length of \(3.0 \text{mm}\), as shown in Fig. 6.2
The wire has diameter \(d\) at cross-section X and diameter \(0.69d\) at cross-section Y
State the name of the class (group) of particles that includes \(\beta^{+}\)
For nucleus X, state the number of
protons,
neutrons
The carbon-13 nucleus has a mass of \(2.2 \times 10^{-26} \text{kg}\). Its kinetic energy as a result of the decay process is \(0.80 \text{MeV}\)
Calculate the speed of this nucleus
Explain why the sum of the kinetic energies of the carbon-13 nucleus and the \(\beta^{+}\) particle cannot be equal to the total energy released by the decay process
A stationary nucleus X decays by emitting a \(\beta^{+}\) particle to form a nucleus of carbon-13 ( \(^{13}_{6}\mathrm{C}\) ). An incomplete equation to represent this decay is
